Questions.QuestionString: Composite materials are used for (level 1)
The fuselage is divided into: (level 1)
Answers: the forward fuselage, the center fuselage and the rear fuselage.
the nose forward fuselage, the forward fuselage, the center fuselage, the rear fuselage, the rear/cone fuselage and the tail cone.
the nose forward fuselage, the forward fuselage, the center fuselage, the rear fuselage, and the cone/rear fuselage.

Questions.QuestionString: The function of the engine pylons installed under each wing is: (level 3)
Answers: support the engine, transmit the engine thrust to the aircraft and enable the routing and attachment of all the systems connected with the engine.
support the engine, transmit the engine thrust to the aircraft and supports the thrust reverser system.
give the engine an aerodynamic shape and supports the thrust reverser system and enable the routing and attachment of all the systems connected with the engine.

Questions.QuestionString: The primary structure of the horizontal stabilizer are: (level 1)
Answers: the spar boxes (Center, Left Hand and Right Hand sides)
the leading edge and the trailing edge.

Questions.QuestionString: The cabin windows are: (level 1)
Answers: installed and removed from the inside and outside of the aircraft.
installed and removed from the outside of the aircraft.
installed and removed from the inside of the aircraft.

Questions.QuestionString: Each outer wing has: (level 1)
Answers: a main structure (outer wing box), a wing tip, a leading edge and leading edge devices, a trailing edge and trailing edge devices.
the wing spars (front and rear), the ribs (1-27), the top and bottom skin panels, the top and bottom stringers, the wing-root joint.
the front and the rear spars, top and bottom skin panels, the two main frames, internal spanwise lattice ribs, the left rib 1 and the right rib 1.

An allowable damage (level 3)
Answers: has significant effect on the strength or fatigue life of the structure.
enables the damaged airplane may be returned into service without repair.
must require minimal rework such as cleanup or drilling of stop holes.

Questions.QuestionString: Fuselage of A320 A/C is divided into? (level 3)
Answers: Three main parts: forward, center and rear fuselage.
Four main parts: nose, forward, center and rear fuselage.
Five main parts: nose forward, forward, center, rear and rear/cone fuselage.

Questions.QuestionString: Pylon box of A320 A/C is made of: (level 3)
A320 A/C THS Tip is made of: (level 3)

The forward fuselage extends from: (level 2)
The pressurized zone of the A/C are: (level 3)
Answers: The radome, wing center box, nose and main gear bays, belly fairing and cone/rear fuselage
The cockpit, cabin, avionics compartment and the FWD and AFT cargo compartments.
The cockpit, cabin, avionics compartment, wing center box, nose and cone/rear fuselage.

Questions.QuestionString: The Structural Repair Manual describes two types of repair which are designed for the repair of structural damage. They are defined as follows: (level 3)
Allowable damage is damage: (level 3)
Answers: which have effected on the structural strength or on other aspects of airworthiness (e.g.: fire resistance, electrical conductivity, system, aerodynamics, aircraft performance, etc.).
which does not have effect on the structural strength or on other aspects of airworthiness (e.g.: fire resistance, electrical conductivity, system, aerodynamics, aircraft performance, etc.).
Which have no repair instruction given in SRM.

Questions.QuestionString: Permanent Repairs are: (level 2)
Answers: Major repairs or major structural replacements requiring special repair drawings and information from the aircraft manufacturers.
Repairs are designed for quick fabrication/installation, and restore ultimate strength. Good appearance, aerodynamic smoothness and maximum fatigue resistance are not required.
Repairs fully restore the structural integrity of the aircraft.

Questions.QuestionString: The dents in metallic parts on external aerodynamic surfaces can cause: (level 2)
Answers: A reduction in flight performance; a good effect on flight characteristics, a bad effect on stall speed; Buffeting.
A reduction in flight performance; a bad effect on flight characteristics, a bad effect on stall speed; Buffeting.

Questions.QuestionString: Primary structure is: (level 2)
Answers: Structure parts significantly transmit ground, flight and pressure load.
Structure parts that do not significantly transmit ground, flight and pressure load.
An element that contributes significantly to the carrying of flight, ground or pressure load, and whose integrity is essential in maintaining the overall structural integrity of the airplane

What is a Category A repair? (level 3)
Answers: A permanent repair and no other actions are necessary.
A permanent repair for which supplemental inspections are necessary at the specified threshold and repeat intervals.
A time-limited repair which must be replaced or reworked within a specified time limit.

Questions.QuestionString: What is a Category B repair? (level 3)
Answers: A permanent repair and no other actions are necessary.
A permanent repair for which supplemental inspections are necessary at the specified threshold and repeat intervals.
A time-limited repair which must be replaced or reworked within a specified time limit.

Questions.QuestionString: What is a Category C repair? (level 3)
Answers: A permanent repair and no other actions are necessary.
A permanent repair for which supplemental inspections are necessary at the specified threshold and repeat intervals.
A time-limited repair which must be replaced or reworked within a specified time limit.

Questions.QuestionString: The crack of structure component causes by: (level 3)
